thread.title: Hotels on track to collect record surcharges and fees this year, report says
thread.title_full: Hotels on track to collect record surcharges and fees this year, report says

author: Charisse Jones , USA TODAY
title: Hotels on track to collect record surcharges and fees this year, report says
text:
Leaving bags with the bell staff after you check out could cost you, as hotels collect billions in fees and surcharges. (Photo: Narayan Mahon, for USA TODAY)
18 CONNECT 43 TWEET 44 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE U.S. hotels are projected to reap a record $2.47 billion this year from fees and surcharges that require guests to pay extra for everything from getting into their room early to leaving bags with the bell staff, according to a new report.
The amount forecast to be collected this year surpasses the record $2.35 billion collected by hotels in 2014, says the report's author, Bjorn Hanson, clinical professor at the New York University School of Professional Studies, Tisch Center for Hospitality and Tourism.
The increased revenue reflects not just a roughly 3% bump in the number of occupied hotel rooms, but an ever-expanding menu of fees that are costing guests more.
"Hotels want to show the lowest possible (room) rate but not lose out on revenue,'' Hanson says. "These surcharges would be a part of that.''
Like the airlines, which reap billions from passengers paying fees to check bags or use in-flight Wi-Fi, hotels are also charging extra for a range of perks and services, including canceling a reservation, receiving a fax in the business center or perhaps using an in-room safe.
With price-sensitive travelers willing to switch hotels based on even a $2 difference in the room rate, Hanson says, and hotels only recently getting back to the profit margins that preceded the Great Recession, properties are eager to find ways to boost revenue.
"Airlines have provided great cover for the hotel industry, because some view the fees charged by airlines as even more harsh,'' Hanson says. "The (hotel) industry is saying ... operating costs have been increasing, and profits per room haven't been until 2013, so we need to find ways to try and catch up with what we didn't achieve over the last several years.''
Some previous revenue streams, like charges for in-room movies and phone calls, may also be fading as guests use their own personal devices. And that may be even more incentive for hotels to get creative, because "there are fewer opportunities for additional sources of revenue,'' Hanson says.
Fees and surcharges vary from hotel to hotel, and the costs may change from day to day. While some fees have existed for decades, one of the newest charges is paying extra to guarantee a particular room, such as one with a king rather than two queen-size beds. Other fees are more common in a particular property type or market. Visitors staying in a Las Vegas resort, for instance, may encounter a charge for being able to check into their room early.
Resort fees, which might cover the use of a gym or swimming pool, are among the most common fees at resort properties, and tend not to be optional. Some consumer advocates say that such mandatory charges should be included in the listed room rate.
"I don't mind fees, in general, as long as it's for optional services,'' says Brett Snyder, president of Cranky Concierge, a travel-assistance service. "Where I see the greatest issue is when there are mandatory fees that you can't avoid, but (which) aren't required to be included in the advertised price.''
Rosanna Maietta, spokeswoman for the American Hotel & Lodging Association, said in an emailed statement that "service fees are common practice in retail and commerce, from banking and mobile fees to extra charges for event tickets.''
She added that "in the hotel industry, mandatory resort fees, often called amenity fees, are fully disclosed at the time of booking and remain transparent whether consumers book online or with the hotel directly. Moreover, resort fees have steadily declined over the past decade. According to a recent survey, a mere 7% of hotels charged mandatory resort fees in 2014.''
Still, Charlie Leocha, chairman of the advocacy group Travelers United, says that while resort fees are disclosed, they are not necessarily on the first page of a booking site that's listing hotels based on room price. His organization wants regulations to require mandatory fees be added to room rates to give consumers a clearer picture up front of how much they will ultimately pay.
"Consumers need to read the fine print on hotel websites, because now the fine print in some cases can increase the cost of the room by 25% to 50%,'' he says. "If you find a hotel with a resort fee, go back to the original listing and click on a different hotel.''
